Title: When ‘A Little Touch of Star Quality’ Is a Little Too Much
Abstract: In upcoming musical revivals, world leaders both real (Imelda Marcos, Eva Perón) and folkloric (King Arthur) get an image makeover they may not deserve.

Title: The Fast and the Curious at Formula 1’s Miami Grand Prix
Abstract: Last summer, diehards and newbies sweated it out in the hot sun for a brief glimpse of pure speed

Title: Gustavo Dudamel, Superstar Maestro, Meets New York
Abstract: On his first visit to the city since being named the New York Philharmonic’s next music director, he eagerly played the role of celebrity conductor.

Title: Iris DeMent Is Worried About the World. So She Made Another Album.
Abstract: The singer and songwriter, 62, takes her time between releases, making sure she has something to say in her music. She has found inspiration once again.

Title: Looted Artifacts, Returned to Yemen, Will Go to the Smithsonian, for Now
Abstract: Under an agreement, ownership of 77 objects seized from a New York art dealer reverted to Yemen. They will be returned when the violent conflict there subsides.

Title: Chase Stokes Turned Down ‘Outer Banks.’ He’s Glad He Reconsidered.
Abstract: The actor plays John B. in the hit Netflix drama, which returns for its third season on Thursday.

Title: Review: In ‘Leo Reich: Literally Who Cares?!,’ He’s Too Hot to Live
Abstract: Reich, a comedian and writer, transforms into the avatar of Gen Z disaffection in his taut, biting solo show at Greenwich House Theater.

Title: Joan Mitchell Foundation Claims Vuitton Ads Infringe on Painter’s Copyright
Abstract: The artist’s organization said it rejected requests from the fashion company to use the artworks in handbag ads, but the luxury brand used them anyway.

Title: SZA Makes It Nine Weeks at No. 1, and Rihanna Returns to Top 10
Abstract: “SOS” is now the longest-running No. 1 album by a woman since Adele’s “25” seven years ago.

Title: What ‘Puss in Boots: The Last Wish’ Owes to Samurai and Sergio Leone
Abstract: The DreamWorks sequel has garnered praise for its vibrant animation, darker story and fight sequences inspired by classic films.

Title: Live Performance in New York: Here’s What to See This Spring
Abstract: “Life of Pi” and Laura Linney on Broadway, Lise Davidsen at the Met Opera, SZA on tour: Here’s what we’re looking forward to this season.

Title: Joshua Bell’s London
Abstract: The celebrated violinist recommends five spots in Britain’s capital, a city he’s visited some 70 times since the 1980s.

Title: Jessica Chastain Returns to the Stage With Nothing to Prove
Abstract: In a pared-down Broadway revival of “A Doll’s House,” the Oscar-winning actress doesn’t have props, period costumes or much of a set. To her surprise, she likes it.

Title: Welcome to New York. Show Us Your Mahler Ninth.
Abstract: This spring, Gustavo Dudamel, the Philharmonic’s next music director, conducts the big deal symphony, the Met Opera stages Terence Blanchard’s “Champion”; and in Chicago, Riccardo Muti says farewell.

Title: Review: Rude T-Shirts and Rude Awakenings in ‘A Bright New Boise’
Abstract: An early play by Samuel D. Hunter finds the author developing his voice by lending it to the lost souls working at an Idaho Hobby Lobby.

Title: Barbara Bosson, 83, Dies; Brought Family Drama to ‘Hill Street Blues’
Abstract: She received five consecutive Emmy nominations for her role as Fay Furillo, the frenetic ex-wife of a police precinct captain.

Title: Adrian Hall, Who Invigorated Regional Theater, Dies at 95
Abstract: As founding artistic director, he made Trinity Rep in Rhode Island a leader in theatrical innovation. He then made his mark in Dallas as well.

Title: ‘The First Fallen’ Review: A Remembrance of Those Passed
Abstract: A director crafts an elegiac tribute set during the dawn of the AIDS crisis in Brazil.

Title: Unionized HarperCollins Employees Are Back to Work After a 3-Month Strike
Abstract: The return, after an agreement that brought a raise in pay for the lowest earners at the publisher, represented a victory to many of the more than 250 workers involved.

Title: We Regret the Fossil Error. It Wasn’t the First.
Abstract: A recent announcement that a fossil discovery in India was just residue from a bee’s nest was a reminder of the importance of science correcting itself.

Title: Laurie Metcalf to Return to Broadway in a Horror Story, ‘Grey House’
Abstract: The play, directed by Joe Mantello and also starring Tatiana Maslany, had a well-reviewed debut in Chicago. It begins performances in April.

Title: ‘Naatu Naatu’ From ‘RRR’ Is a Worldwide Hit, but It Draws on Very Local Traditions
Abstract: The composers and choreographer explain how they created the propulsive sequence that is nominated for best song.

Title: An Unlikely College Bromance That Has Lasted a Lifetime
Abstract: In his new memoir, Will Schwalbe — theater nerd and bookworm — describes the bond he continues to share with a former Navy SEAL turned eco-warrior.

Title: Cocaine Bear, Meet Cannabis Raccoon and McFlurry Skunk
Abstract: Wild animals eat the strangest things. That can be a problem, for them and for us.

Title: Huey ‘Piano’ Smith, New Orleans Rock ’n’ Roll Cornerstone, Dies at 89
Abstract: With songs like “Don’t You Just Know It,” “Rocking Pneumonia and the Boogie Woogie Flu” and “Sea Cruise,” he put a firm backbeat behind joyful nonsense.

Title: Christian McBride, Revered in Jazz, Is Playing the Long Game
Abstract: At 50, the bassist is always focused on the next gig and fresh collaborations. His 18th album as a band leader is due this month.

Title: Review: A New Opera Puts Real Emotions in a Fantasy Garden
Abstract: Kate Soper’s “The Romance of the Rose,” which had its long-delayed premiere at Long Beach Opera, showcases her signature quick-shifting eclecticism.

Title: Richard Belzer Had a Ball With the Relationship Between Comic and Crowd
Abstract: Unlike his TV characters, his live shows were marked by spontaneity and physicality. He could even keep up with Robin Williams line by line.

Title: ‘Rust’ Prosecutors Downgrade Alec Baldwin’s Manslaughter Charges
Abstract: The actor’s lawyers had argued that a firearm law included by the prosecutors was not in effect at the time of the fatal shooting. It would have carried a mandatory five-year sentence.

Title: Roald Dahl’s Books Are Rewritten to Cut Potentially Offensive Language
Abstract: New editions of the best-selling author’s children’s classics, including “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” have been altered to eliminate words deemed inappropriate. A backlash ensued.

Title: An Artist’s Queer Take on ‘Moby-Dick’
Abstract: Wu Tsang has mined Herman Melville’s classic novel to create ambitious, provocative spectacles.

Title: ‘Black Bear,’ ‘Sharp Stick’ and More Streaming Gems
Abstract: Looking for something different to stream? We have options for you.

Title: Review: ‘Die Monosau’ Revives Chaotic Energy in Berlin
Abstract: Chaos also plays a role in a new play at the Volksbühne theater that delivers on its pledge of a director-free evening.

Title: Cambodia Says It Has Recovered Looted Gold Jewelry Once Worn by Royals
Abstract: The 77 items had been in the collection of Douglas A.J. Latchford, accused of trafficking in looted antiquities, and were returned under an agreement with his estate.
